title: 109_hr1226
content: The Act is titled the "United States Financial Policy Committee For Fair Capital Standards Act." It establishes the United States Financial Policy Committee. The "United States Financial Policy Committee" is established with key members including the Secretary of the Treasury and the Chairman of the Federal Reserve. Its purpose is to develop US positions on proposals affecting financial institutions. The Committee must meet before Basel Committee meetings on capital standards and as requested by the Chairperson or any member. Members must adhere to Committee positions in Basel Committee negotiations, with the Secretary of the Treasury's position being determinative in case of disagreement. Reports to Congress are required. The Committee is required to submit an annual report to Congress on its proceedings, including a brief description of issues addressed and uniform positions developed. If there is a disagreement on a particular issue, the report must also include a brief description of the parties' positions and an explanation of the disagreement. The Committee must report to Congress on its proceedings annually, including issues addressed and positions developed. If there is a disagreement, the report must explain the reasons. Federal banking agencies must consult with Congress before agreeing to Basel Committee recommendations. The Federal banking agencies, in consultation with the Secretary of the Treasury, will evaluate the impact of the revised Capital Accord on factors such as cost, complexity, impact on financial institutions, real estate markets, operational risk capital standards, and competition. The Committee will require additional training for supervision and examination personnel, public comments will be accepted for a minimum of 60 days, and the impact of compliance by domestic banks will be assessed. Each agency on the Committee will provide necessary administrative support services. Representation on Basel Committee for Director of Office of Thrift Supervision. The International Lending Supervision Act of 1983 is amended to give the Director of the Office of Thrift Supervision equal representation on the Committee on Banking Regulations and Supervisory Practices. The International Lending Supervision Act of 1983 is amended to provide equal representation for the FDIC and the Director of the Office of Thrift Supervision on the Committee on Banking Regulations and Supervisory Practices.
